title: About
content:
Hi there!
I‚Äôm a Hong Kong-born, Taipei and Shanghai raised strategist who lives in New York by way of San Francisco.
I enjoy working on projects that facilitate connections between people and the cities they inhabit. Some of these projects include: Message in a Bottle, Pillars of Reflection, and The Breakup Coloring Book.
I’ve also been lucky to make great work with many companies while at Dropbox, Goodby Silverstein & Partners, Naked Communications, and Wieden+Kennedy, including:
  Dropbox‚Äîdeveloping the company’s first brand architecture, establishing foundational principles for brand building, and working on everything brand-related, including: naming, logos, icons, events, partnerships, guidelines, product videos, campaigns, blogs, company mission, and design strategy.
  Adobe‚Äîmaking fun of marketers (Exhibits A , B , C , among many) and launching a stock photography site.   Doritos‚Äîgetting ridiculous at the Superbowl and extending the Doritos brand beyond its signature slapstick humor with efforts like Doritos Rainbows and Doritos No Choice.   Milwaukee Bucks‚Äîdoing the brand strategy work that began the revitalization of a 50+ year old NBA franchise deep in NBA purgatory (this was in 2013, the year they drafted an 18 year old unknown by the name of Giannis Antetokounmpo).
  In my spare time, I‚Äôm a hoops junkie, an ex-online poker player who miraculously recovered his funds from the DOJ, and a cyclist who somehow misses the hills of San Francisco.
If you’d like to follow my personal projects, this newsletter is the best way to do that. You can also find me at:
 email: etiennehma@gmail.com
instagram: etiennehma twitter: etiennehma

title: Message in a Bottle
content:
üçº Message In a Bottle #  In close collaboration with Danny Witters, Tim Wei, and Han Yang Lee.
 Thousands of strangers leave voicemails for each other.¬†What do they say?
  Message in a Bottle was an anonymous hotline that let strangers leave voicemails for each other. Each caller left a message; then they heard what the previous caller left behind.
We left hundreds of placards with the phone number in San Francisco, New York City, London, and Sao Paulo‚Äîout on the streets, in bathrooms, in parks‚Äîand over 3000 people dialed in, leaving messages that were surprising, creative, vulnerable, and often delightful.
You can listen to all of the messages here: https://messages.city.

title: Pillars of Reflection
content:
üí≠ Pillars of Reflection #  In close collaboration with Tim Wei
   Tim and I built Pillars of Reflection as part of the Market Street Prototyping Festival organized by San Francisco Planning and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.¬†Pillars was a mirror installation designed to get people to stop for a moment as they walked along Market Street.¬†The Pillars were the subject of many curious stares, selfies, smiles, and even a birthday celebration.
                              Behind the scenes, if you’re curious:

title: The Breakup Coloring Book
content:
üíî The Breakup Coloring Book #  In close collaboration with Fu Le and Leon Lin.
 The Breakup Coloring Book is filled with wise sayings from cultures all around the world‚Äîthings that people say to comfort people who have just broken up.
       Things like ‚Äúthere‚Äôs plenty of fish in the sea‚Äù (English) and ‚Äúthere are orange trees elsewhere that grow oranges‚Äù (Greek) and ‚Äúdon’t give up the entire forest for a single tree‚Äù (Chinese).
Each saying is illustrated so that anyone going through a breakup can color it in and soothe their aching heart.
The project was funded via generous supporters on Kickstarter, where it was selected as one of the site’s “Projects We Love.”

title: Likemind
content:
üß† Likemind #   Who’s reading the same books as me?
     An experiment conducted over five hundred notecards, each with the message above, placed in books that have resonated with me.¬†The notecards are scattered across book shops, thrift stores, and libraries in Philadelphia, New York, Boston, Providence, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Salt Lake City, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Melbourne.
To date, 23 folks have reached out to say hi.

title: A Personal Corner of the Internet
content:
I‚Äôve been feeling like I don’t have a place on the internet anymore. It’s become a mall, homogenized by the Facebooks, Instagrams, Twitters, and YouTubes. Everything has a similar aesthetic. Everything is geared towards likes and follows.
I miss the land of Geocities, and Xanga, and even MySpace, where pockets of the internet were weirder and more individualized. We weren‚Äôt so focused on building audiences or brands; we just made things because it was kind of amazing that we had this new canvas for expression.
That‚Äôs what this blog is. An attempt to stake out my personal corner of the internet. No likes, no follows, no analytics. Just a record of what I‚Äôm working on and what‚Äôs been interesting to me. And maybe it‚Äôll be interesting to you too‚Äîno pressure though.
